title: Genesis Chapter 15 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Genesis chapter 15 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Genesis Chapter 15 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Genesis Chapter 15.

questions.question: Who spoke to Abram in a vision saying, 'Fear not, Abram: I am thy shield, and thy exceeding great reward'?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:1 states that the word of the LORD came unto Abram in a vision, saying these words.

questions.question: According to Genesis 15:2, who was the steward of Abram's house?
questions.correctAnswer: Eliezer of Damascus
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:2 identifies Eliezer of Damascus as the steward of Abram's house.

questions.question: What did the LORD say would not be Abram's heir?
options: A son born in Abram's house
questions.correctAnswer: A son born in Abram's house
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:4 says the LORD told Abram that the steward born in his house shall not be his heir.

questions.question: What did God instruct Abram to do to show him the number of his descendants?
options: Look toward heaven and count the stars
questions.correctAnswer: Look toward heaven and count the stars
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:5 says God brought Abram outside and told him to look toward heaven and count the stars as a symbol of his descendants.

questions.question: What was counted to Abram for righteousness?
questions.correctAnswer: His belief in the LORD
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:6 states that Abram believed in the LORD, and it was counted to him for righteousness.

questions.question: From where did the LORD say He brought Abram?
questions.correctAnswer: Ur of the Chaldees
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:7 says the LORD brought Abram out of Ur of the Chaldees.

questions.question: What animals did the LORD command Abram to take for the covenant ceremony?
options: Heifer, she goat, ram, turtledove, and young pigeon
Cow, sheep, ox, dove, and raven
Horse, camel, goat, pigeon, and sparrow
Heifer, lamb, ram, eagle, and dove
questions.correctAnswer: Heifer, she goat, ram, turtledove, and young pigeon
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:9 lists these specific animals as the ones Abram was to take.

questions.question: What did Abram do with the animals during the covenant ceremony?
options: Divided them in the midst and laid each piece opposite another
questions.correctAnswer: Divided them in the midst and laid each piece opposite another
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:10 describes how Abram divided the animals and laid each piece opposite the other.

questions.question: What happened to Abram when the sun was going down during the covenant ceremony?
options: A deep sleep and horror of great darkness fell upon him
He fell to the ground and fainted
questions.correctAnswer: A deep sleep and horror of great darkness fell upon him
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:12 states that a deep sleep and horror of great darkness fell upon Abram at sunset.

questions.question: According to Genesis 15:13, how long shall Abram's seed be strangers and afflicted in a land not theirs?
questions.correctAnswer: Four hundred years
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:13 clearly states that Abram’s seed will be afflicted for four hundred years in a foreign land.

questions.question: True or False: Genesis 15:14 says that the nation whom Abram's seed serves will be judged by God.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:14 states that God will judge the nation that serves Abram's seed.

questions.question: True or False: Abram will die in battle according to Genesis 15:15.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:15 says Abram will go to his fathers in peace and be buried at a good old age, not in battle.

questions.question: True or False: The iniquity of the Amorites was full at the time of God's covenant with Abram.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:16 explains that the iniquity of the Amorites was not yet full.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Genesis 15:18: 'Unto thy seed have I given this land, from the river of Egypt unto the great river, the river ________.'
questions.correctAnswer: Euphrates
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:18 clearly states the river Euphrates as the boundary of the land given to Abram's seed.

questions.question: Which of these peoples is NOT listed as inhabitants of the land promised to Abram's seed?
questions.correctAnswer: Philistines
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:19-21 lists Kenites, Hittites, Amorites, but not Philistines.

medium.title: Genesis Chapter 15 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Genesis Chapter 15 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Genesis 15, what biblical truth about faith and trust would you share?
options: God rewards faith and counts it as righteousness
Faith is not necessary if you have good works
Righteousness comes from keeping the law perfectly
questions.correctAnswer: God rewards faith and counts it as righteousness
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:6 shows Abram believed God and it was counted to him for righteousness; this teaches that trusting God is key to righteousness. Also see Genesis 15:1, 15:5 for God's promises and Abram's trust.

questions.question: How does Genesis 15 teach about God’s reassurance in times of fear and uncertainty?
options: God tells Abram not to fear because He is his shield and reward
God tells Abram to face his fears alone
God advises Abram to rely only on his own strength
questions.correctAnswer: God tells Abram not to fear because He is his shield and reward
questions.explanation: In Genesis 15:1, God reassures Abram with 'Fear not, Abram: I am thy shield, and thy exceeding great reward,' showing God’s protection and provision during uncertainty.

questions.question: A believer struggles with doubt about God’s promises regarding family and legacy. What biblical truth from Genesis 15 would encourage them?
options: God promises descendants as numerous as the stars
God says no descendants will come
Only a servant will inherit the family
Legacy depends solely on human effort
questions.correctAnswer: God promises descendants as numerous as the stars
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:5 shows God’s promise to Abram about his seed being as numerous as the stars, encouraging trust in God’s faithfulness despite present circumstances. Related verses: 15:2-4, 15:6.

questions.question: How does Genesis 15 illustrate the importance of seeking confirmation from God in decision-making or inheritance concerns?
options: Abram asks God how he will know he will inherit the land
Abram does not question God’s promise
Abram relies on his servants for answers
Abram gives up hope without confirmation
questions.correctAnswer: Abram asks God how he will know he will inherit the land
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:8 shows Abram's honest question seeking assurance, teaching believers to seek God’s confirmation in important matters with humility and faith. Also see 15:7, 15:9-17.

questions.question: In terms of obedience and spiritual discipline, what lesson can be drawn from Abram’s actions in Genesis 15 regarding God’s instructions?
options: Abram faithfully prepares the animals as instructed by God
Abram changes the instructions to suit himself
questions.correctAnswer: Abram faithfully prepares the animals as instructed by God
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:9-10 describes Abram taking the specific animals and dividing them as God commanded, demonstrating obedience and reverence to God’s word. See also 15:12-17 for God's covenant ceremony.

questions.question: How does Genesis 15 teach about perseverance through trials and trusting God’s timing?
options: God promises that though Abram’s descendants will be afflicted, they will be delivered in time
God promises immediate deliverance without trials
Trials mean God has abandoned His promises
Perseverance is not needed if the promise seems delayed
questions.correctAnswer: God promises that though Abram’s descendants will be afflicted, they will be delivered in time
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:13-14 assures that Abram’s descendants will be strangers and serve others for 400 years but will come out with great substance, teaching trust in God’s timing and purpose through trials. See also 15:15-16.

questions.question: What biblical truth about contentment and peace does Genesis 15 offer concerning the end of life?
options: Abram will go to his fathers in peace and be buried at a good old age
Abram will die in turmoil and uncertainty
The promise of peace is not given to Abram
Abram is told he will have a short and troubled life
questions.correctAnswer: Abram will go to his fathers in peace and be buried at a good old age
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:15 states Abram will go to his fathers in peace and have a good old age, teaching believers about God’s provision for a peaceful end and contentment in His care. See 15:1, 15:6 for God's faithfulness.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with doubt about God’s promises. Based on Genesis 15, what practical advice about faith and righteousness can you give?
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:6 teaches that Abram believed God and it was credited to him as righteousness, showing that faith, not works, is the basis for righteousness. This encourages believers to trust God confidently.

questions.question: Does Genesis 15 indicate that God’s promises to Abram include a specific territorial inheritance?
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:18-21 records God’s covenant giving Abram’s descendants a specific land from the river of Egypt to the Euphrates including various peoples’ lands, confirming God’s promise of inheritance.

questions.question: How does Genesis 15 teach about humility and reliance on God rather than human strength or status?
options: Abram acknowledges he is childless and questions God
Abram boasts about his wealth and servants
Abram relies solely on Eliezer, his steward
Abram tries to take the land by force
questions.correctAnswer: Abram acknowledges he is childless and questions God
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:2-3 shows Abram honestly admitting his childlessness and lack of heirs, demonstrating humility and dependence on God’s promise rather than his own status or resources. See also 15:4-5.

questions.question: What spiritual discipline can be gleaned from Abram’s experience of a deep sleep and vision in Genesis 15?
options: God reveals important truths during moments of spiritual rest and revelation
God only speaks during loud, dramatic events
Spiritual insight requires no rest or reflection
questions.correctAnswer: God reveals important truths during moments of spiritual rest and revelation
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:12 describes a deep sleep and a vision where God reveals future events to Abram, teaching that spiritual growth involves times of reflection and divine revelation. See also 15:13-17.

questions.question: How does Genesis 15 teach about God’s faithfulness in keeping His promises over generations?
options: God promises Abram’s descendants will inherit the land despite future trials
God’s promises are only for Abram’s lifetime
God’s promises depend on human perfection
God will forget His promises if people sin
questions.correctAnswer: God promises Abram’s descendants will inherit the land despite future trials
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:16-18 shows God’s covenant with Abram extending to his descendants, promising land and restoration even after affliction, demonstrating God’s long-term faithfulness. See also 15:13-15.

questions.question: A believer is uncertain about the future and inheritance of God’s promises. Based on Genesis 15, what encouragement can you provide about God’s covenant?
options: God made a covenant with Abram confirming the land to his seed
God’s promises are vague and without guarantee
God’s covenant was only verbal with no sign
God’s covenant was conditional on Abram’s wealth
questions.correctAnswer: God made a covenant with Abram confirming the land to his seed
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:17-18 describes God making a covenant with Abram including a smoking furnace and burning lamp passing between pieces, confirming the promise of land to Abram’s descendants. See also 15:9-10.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: In Genesis 15, God tells Abram that his descendants will be strangers in a land not their own and will serve them and be afflicted for ______ years.
questions.correctAnswer: four hundred
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:13 states that Abram’s seed will be afflicted for four hundred years, teaching believers to trust God’s plan through periods of hardship.

questions.question: How does Genesis 15 teach about God as a protector and rewarder in the life of a believer?
options: God identifies Himself as Abram’s shield and exceeding great reward
God promises only hardships with no reward
God is distant and uninvolved in Abram’s life
God requires Abram to earn his reward by works
questions.correctAnswer: God identifies Himself as Abram’s shield and exceeding great reward
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:1 shows God calling Himself Abram’s shield and great reward, teaching believers about God’s protective care and generous provision. See also 15:6, 15:15.

questions.question: What does Genesis 15 teach about the importance of honesty in prayer and communication with God?
options: Abram honestly expresses his concerns about having no heir
Abram hides his doubts and fears from God
questions.correctAnswer: Abram honestly expresses his concerns about having no heir
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:2-3 records Abram expressing his childlessness and concerns honestly to God, modeling openness in prayer and reliance on God’s answers. See also 15:8.

hard.title: Genesis Chapter 15 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Genesis Chapter 15.

questions.question: In Genesis 15:6, Abram's belief in the LORD was counted to him as what?
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:6 states that Abram believed in the LORD, and it was counted to him for righteousness, highlighting the foundational biblical theme of faith being credited as righteousness.

questions.question: What does the LORD identify Himself as in His first message to Abram in Genesis 15:1?
options: Thy shield and exceeding great reward
questions.correctAnswer: Thy shield and exceeding great reward
questions.explanation: In Genesis 15:1, God reassures Abram by declaring Himself as his shield and great reward, emphasizing divine protection and blessing.

questions.question: According to Genesis 15:5, what analogy does God use to describe Abram's future descendants?
options: Grains of sand on the shore
questions.correctAnswer: Stars in the heaven
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:5 uses the stars as a metaphor for the innumerable descendants that Abram will have, illustrating the vastness of God's promise.

questions.question: What question does Abram ask God regarding the inheritance of the land in Genesis 15:8?
options: How will I find the land?
Where shall I bury my fathers?
Whereby shall I know that I shall inherit it?
questions.correctAnswer: Whereby shall I know that I shall inherit it?
questions.explanation: In Genesis 15:8, Abram seeks assurance about inheriting the land, prompting God to establish a covenant with him.

questions.question: Which animals did God instruct Abram to bring for the covenant ceremony in Genesis 15:9?
options: A heifer, a she goat, a ram, a turtledove, and a young pigeon
A lamb, a dove, a goat, a calf, and a raven
A lion, a bear, a leopard, a ram, and a turtle dove
A bull, a ram, a goat, a sparrow, and a pigeon
questions.correctAnswer: A heifer, a she goat, a ram, a turtledove, and a young pigeon
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:9 lists these specific animals as part of the covenant ritual, reflecting ancient Near Eastern treaty practices.

questions.question: What significant event happened to Abram when the sun was going down as described in Genesis 15:12?
options: A deep sleep and horror of great darkness fell upon him
He saw angels ascending and descending
questions.correctAnswer: A deep sleep and horror of great darkness fell upon him
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:12 describes Abram entering a deep sleep accompanied by a terrifying darkness, which is often interpreted as a divine revelation or vision.

questions.question: According to Genesis 15:13, how long will Abram's descendants be strangers and afflicted in a land not theirs?
questions.correctAnswer: 400 years
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:13 prophesies that Abram's seed will be strangers and afflicted for four hundred years, foreshadowing the Egyptian bondage.

questions.question: Which event in Genesis 15:17 symbolizes the ratification of the covenant between God and Abram?
options: A smoking furnace and a burning lamp passing between pieces
A rainbow appearing in the sky
A dove descending with an olive branch
questions.correctAnswer: A smoking furnace and a burning lamp passing between pieces
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:17 describes the smoking furnace and burning lamp passing between the divided animals as a typical ancient Near Eastern sign of covenant making.

questions.question: The land promised to Abram in Genesis 15:18 extends from the river of Egypt to which river?
questions.correctAnswer: The Euphrates
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:18 specifies the covenant land boundaries as from the river of Egypt to the great river, the Euphrates, defining the extent of the promised inheritance.

questions.question: Which of the following nations is NOT listed as inhabitants of the promised land in Genesis 15:19-21?
questions.correctAnswer: Philistines
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:19-21 lists several nations inhabiting the land, including Amorites, Hittites, and Kenites, but does not mention Philistines here.

questions.question: True or False: According to Genesis 15:4, the steward of Abram's house, Eliezer of Damascus, will be his heir.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:4 clarifies that Eliezer will not be Abram's heir; instead, the heir will come from Abram's own body.

questions.question: What promise does God make about Abram's death in Genesis 15:15?
options: He will die young and be forgotten
He will go to his fathers in peace and be buried at a good old age
He will never see his descendants
He will be taken to heaven without dying
questions.correctAnswer: He will go to his fathers in peace and be buried at a good old age
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:15 assures Abram that he will die peacefully and at an old age, signifying a blessed life.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'fear not' in God's initial word to Abram in Genesis 15:1, considering the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: It shows God's superiority over other gods
It reassures Abram amid a common environment of threat and uncertainty
It is a command to be brave in battle
It indicates that Abram had no fear of death
questions.correctAnswer: It reassures Abram amid a common environment of threat and uncertainty
questions.explanation: The phrase 'fear not' in Genesis 15:1 functions as divine encouragement to Abram in a hostile ancient Near Eastern context, highlighting God's protective role.

questions.question: How does the covenant ceremony in Genesis 15 reflect typical ancient Near Eastern treaty practices?
options: By dividing animals and passing between them
By building an altar of stones
questions.correctAnswer: By dividing animals and passing between them
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:9-17 describes dividing animals and the divine presence passing between them, mirroring ancient treaty rituals symbolizing binding agreements.

questions.question: True or False: The promise in Genesis 15:16 states that Abram's descendants will return to the promised land after the iniquity of the Amorites is full.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:16 confirms that Abram's descendants will return in the fourth generation because the Amorites' iniquity is not yet complete, indicating divine timing.

theological.title: Genesis Chapter 15 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Genesis Chapter 15 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Genesis 15:6, Abram's belief in the LORD was accounted to him for what?
questions.correctAnswer: Righteousness
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:6 states that Abram believed the LORD, and it was counted to him for righteousness. This foundational truth is echoed in Romans 4:3, Galatians 3:6, James 2:23, and Hebrews 11:8, showing that faith is credited as righteousness by God.

questions.question: What did God promise Abram regarding his descendants in Genesis 15:5?
options: They would be as numerous as the stars
They would inherit the land immediately
questions.correctAnswer: They would be as numerous as the stars
questions.explanation: In Genesis 15:5, God tells Abram to count the stars if he can, declaring that so shall his seed be. This promise of innumerable descendants is foundational to the Abrahamic covenant and is reiterated in Hebrews 11:12 and Galatians 3:16, highlighting God's faithful fulfillment.

questions.question: According to Genesis 15:4, who would be Abram's heir?
options: One born of his own body
questions.correctAnswer: One born of his own body
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:4 clarifies that Abram's heir would not be his steward but one coming from his own bowels. This points to the promise of a biological descendant, fulfilled in Isaac (Genesis 21:12) and ultimately pointing to Christ as the seed of Abraham (Galatians 3:16).

questions.question: What sign did God give Abram to confirm the promise of the land in Genesis 15:9-10?
questions.correctAnswer: Divided animal sacrifices
questions.explanation: In Genesis 15:9-10, God instructs Abram to bring specific animals and divide them, laying pieces opposite each other as a covenant sign. This ancient covenant ceremony is referenced in Jeremiah 34:18 and Hebrews 9:18-20, symbolizing God's binding promise to Abram.

questions.question: What covenantal sign appeared in Genesis 15:17 to confirm the covenant between God and Abram?
options: A smoking furnace and a burning lamp
A dove with an olive branch
questions.correctAnswer: A smoking furnace and a burning lamp
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:17 describes a smoking furnace and a burning lamp passing between the animal pieces, symbolizing God's presence and sealing the covenant. This divine manifestation highlights God's unchanging faithfulness, as seen in Exodus 13:21 and Isaiah 4:5.

questions.question: According to Genesis 15:13, what would happen to Abram's descendants in a land not theirs?
options: They would serve and be afflicted for 400 years
They would immediately inherit the land
questions.correctAnswer: They would serve and be afflicted for 400 years
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:13 reveals that Abram's descendants would be strangers in a foreign land, serving and afflicted for 400 years. This prophecy is fulfilled in Israel's slavery in Egypt (Exodus 12:40-41) and points to God's sovereign plan in salvation history (Acts 7:6).

questions.question: What assurance does God give Abram about his personal future in Genesis 15:15?
options: He would wander all his life
He would die in peace and a good old age
He would never see his descendants
questions.correctAnswer: He would die in peace and a good old age
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:15 promises Abram that he shall go to his fathers in peace and be buried in a good old age. This assurance of a peaceful end is consistent with God's care for His covenant people, as reflected in Psalms 91:16 and Proverbs 3:2.

questions.question: Which group is NOT mentioned as inhabitants of the land promised to Abram in Genesis 15:19-21?
questions.correctAnswer: Philistines
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:19-21 lists the Kenites, Kenizzites, Kadmonites, Hittites, Perizzites, Rephaims, Amorites, Canaanites, Girgashites, and Jebusites as inhabitants of the land. The Philistines are not mentioned here, though they appear elsewhere (Exodus 13:17), indicating the specific groups in this covenant context.

questions.question: What did Abram ask God to provide to know he would inherit the land, as recorded in Genesis 15:8?
questions.correctAnswer: A covenant confirmation
questions.explanation: In Genesis 15:8, Abram asks God how he will know that he will inherit the land, seeking assurance. God's response with the covenant ceremony in verses 9-21 serves as the confirmation, highlighting God's faithfulness to His promises (Hebrews 6:13-18).

questions.question: Which animals did God instruct Abram to bring for the covenant ceremony in Genesis 15:9?
options: A heifer, a she goat, a ram, a turtledove, and a young pigeon
questions.correctAnswer: A heifer, a she goat, a ram, a turtledove, and a young pigeon
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:9 lists the specific animals God commands Abram to bring for the covenant: a three-year-old heifer, she goat, ram, plus a turtledove and young pigeon. This detailed ritual signifies the solemnity of the covenant, similar to other sacrificial practices in Leviticus 1.

questions.question: What did God identify Himself as to Abram in Genesis 15:7?
options: The LORD who brought him out of Ur
The Creator of heaven and earth
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD who brought him out of Ur
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:7 reveals God identifying Himself as the LORD who brought Abram out of Ur of the Chaldees to give him the land to inherit. This emphasizes God's providential guidance and covenantal promise, foundational to Israel's identity (Exodus 3:6; Isaiah 41:8-10).

questions.question: What was the significance of the deep sleep and horror of great darkness that fell upon Abram in Genesis 15:12?
options: It was a sign of judgment
It was God preparing Abram for covenant revelation
It was a test of faith
questions.correctAnswer: It was God preparing Abram for covenant revelation
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:12 describes a deep sleep and horror of great darkness falling on Abram, preparing him for God's revelation about his descendants' future. This parallels other divine encounters involving sleep or visions (Isaiah 6:1; Daniel 10:9), underscoring divine initiative in covenant revelation.

questions.question: In Genesis 15:14, what will God do to the nation that enslaves Abram's descendants?
questions.correctAnswer: Judge them
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:14 promises that God will judge the nation that enslaves Abram's descendants. This judgment is part of God's redemptive plan, as seen in the Exodus narrative and prophetic books (Exodus 12:12; Isaiah 10:5-19), showing God's justice on behalf of His people.

questions.question: According to Genesis 15:16, why will Abram's descendants return to the land in the fourth generation?
options: Because the Amorites' iniquity is not yet full
questions.correctAnswer: Because the Amorites' iniquity is not yet full
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:16 states that Abram's descendants will return to the land in the fourth generation because the Amorites' iniquity is not yet full. This shows God's righteous timing in judgment, a theme also seen in Genesis 18:20-21 and Romans 9:22-23.

questions.question: What does Genesis 15:1 reveal about God's character in His speech to Abram?
options: God is a shield and exceeding great reward
God is indifferent to Abram's fears
questions.correctAnswer: God is a shield and exceeding great reward
questions.explanation: Genesis 15:1 shows God comforting Abram, declaring Himself as his shield and exceeding great reward. This reveals God's protective and generous nature, consistent with Psalms 28:7, 2 Samuel 22:3, and Romans 8:32.
